title: Observing Supernovae
content:
Rubin Observatory monitors millions of galaxies on a regular basis and is contributing to a huge increase in the number of supernovae discovered each night. Itâ€™s your turn to examine some of these recently-discovered supernovae

Find the supernova by stepping through the images below. Once you have located the supernova and clicked on it, you will see a set of observations of the magnitude of the supernova at different times on the graph at the right. This is known as a light curve. Now advance through all of the other images of the supernova and watch as the corresponding magnitude of the supernova in the image is selected on the graph.
